thread.title: Erin Coleman considers run for Nashville Senate seat
thread.title_full: Erin Coleman considers run for Nashville Senate seat

title: Erin Coleman considers run for Nashville Senate seat
text:
Erin Coleman considers run for Nashville Senate seat Joey Garrison , jgarrison@tennessean.com 5:07 p.m. CDT October 22, 2015 Erin Coleman (Photo: Submitted) 
Erin Coleman surprised politicos last month by finishing a close sixth in the race for five Metro Council at-large seats despite being relatively new to Nashville politics. 
Now, she has her eyes set on the Tennessee state legislature as she weighs a Democratic primary run for the state Senate to challenge freshman GOP Sen. Steve Dickerson. 
Coleman, a civil engineer, attorney and military veteran who lives in Nashville’s Whitland neighborhood, confirmed to The Tennessean that she’s considering running for the District 20 seat as a Democrat. She said she expects to make a decision by the beginning of 2016. 
“You have more of a broad stretch of issues that you’re dealing with than what the Metro Council deals with,” Coleman said of her interest in state politics. “You’re talking about health care, schools, guns — all of these issues that are so important and pressing right now in our state and country. 
“I think someone with a diverse background such as my own, when it comes to being a military veteran to being a mother of three, would be a good addition to the Senate (Democratic) Caucus.” 
Dickerson, among the more moderate Republicans in the Republican-dominated state legislature, defeated Democrat Phillip North by a 54 percent to 46 percent margin in the 2010 open race to replace former Sen. Joe Haynes. He faces his first re-election test next year. 
In last month's Metro runoff election, Coleman finished just 2,799 votes behind Jim Shulman for the fifth at-large seat in the Metro Council. 
The geographically winding District 20 — Nashville’s only Senate seat that leans to the right — encompasses the neighborhoods of Belle Meade, Forrest Hills, Belle Meade and Bellevue, as well as the far northern part of Davidson County, including Goodlettsville and Joelton. 
In a 2016 election cycle that is likely to once again be tough for Tennessee Democrats, District 20 could be one of their best chances to pick off a legislative seat from Republicans.
